docs.lead_paragraph: After months of criticism from the families of those killed on Sept. 11, the Bush administration is close to a decision on several changes in the Victims Compensation Fund that could result in scores of families' receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars more than the fund's original rules would have allowed. The new rules would also open the fund to hundreds of additional rescue workers and World Trade Center employees who were injured in the attack, including those who suffered disabling lung ailments.

headline.main: U.S. MAY APPROVE MORE AID FOR KIN OF SEPT. 11 DEAD

docs.abstract: Bush administration, after months of criticism from families of those killed in September 11 terrorist attacks, nears decision on several changes in Victims Compensation Fund that could result in scores of families' receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars more than fund's original rules allow; new rules would open fund to hundreds of additional rescue workers and World Trade Center employees injured in attack, including those who suffered disabling lung ailments; would also reduce various deductions that have potential of cutting awards by hundreds of thousands of dollars; amount to spouses and children for noneconomic damages like loss of companionship would go to $100,000 from $50,000; other likely changes discussed; fund director Kenneth R Feinberg comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: After months of criticism from the families of those killed on Sept. 11, the Bush administration is close to a decision on several changes in the Victims Compensation Fund that could result in scores of families' receiving hundreds of thousands of...
docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a tangle of wires and worried faces, the brief life of Joshua Diaz was slipping away, and Dr. Mitchell R. Goldstein knew he must soon make an agonizing decision. For 30 minutes, Dr. Goldstein's emergency team had medically assaulted the 2-week-old baby with lifesaving measures, none of which appeared to be working. Worse, a device called a pulse oximeter failed to detect a pulse or show how much oxygen Joshua's blood was ferrying to his vital organs.

headline.main: Questions Raised of Conflicts At 2 Hospital Buying Groups

docs.abstract: Article in ongoing series, Medicine's Middleman, on organizations that negotiate purchasing contracts with suppliers of nation's hospitals; focuses on conflict-of-interest issues raised by Premier Inc and Novation, middlemen for approximately half of nation's nonprofit hospitals who negotiated contracts for estimated $34 billion in hospital supplies in 2001; extensive and highly unusual ties to medical supply companies have raised question over whether their mission to use market power of more than 1,500 hospitals to find best medical products at lowest prices, is being compromised; problem stems from fact that groups are financed not by hospitals that buy products, but by companies that sell them and make money from very companies they are supposed to evaluate objectively; each year, companies pay Premier and Novation hundreds of millions of dollars in fees that represent percentage of hospital purchases; more hospitals spend on medical supplies, more money both companies get from suppliers; Premier and some of its officials have also received stocks or options from companies which Premier contracts; small manufacturers complain of competitive disadvantage; say they have been effectively blocked by groups, which have secured exclusive contracts with hospitals and largely determine which products many hospitals buy; critics say such conflicts of interest can mean that buying groups do not always choose products that are best for patients, hospitals or taxpayers or insurance that pays their bills; photos; drawings (L)

byline.original: This article was reported by Walt Bogdanich, Barry Meier and Mary Williams Walsh and was written by Mr. Bogdanich

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's top economic advisers have presented him with proposals to rescue the American steel industry that would most heavily penalize China, Japan, Germany, Taiwan and South Korea, but exempt most poor nations -- and Mexico and Canada -- from punishing tariffs. With Mr. Bush facing a deadline that requires him to announce a decision by Wednesday, the advisers are seeking a way for him to argue that he is making good on his campaign promises to ailing steel makers and steelworkers, particularly in states like West Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio that are vital to the Republicans in this year's Congressional election.

headline.main: Bush Weighs Raising Steel Tariffs But Exempting Most Poor Nations

docs.abstract: Pres Bush's top advisers present him with proposals to rescue American steel industry that would most heavily penalize China, Japan, Germany, Taiwan and South Korea, but exempt most poor nations as well as Canada and Mexico from punishing tariffs; are seeking way for him to argue he is making good on campaign promises to ailing steel makers and steelworkers, particularly in states like West Virginia and Pennsylvania, which are vital in upcoming Congressional elections; proposals fall well short of what some steelmakers and unions have demanded, namely, 40 percent tariffs on virtually all steel products from abroad; Bush appears set to reject industry efforts to have government assume pension and health liabilities of failed steel makers, move US Steel has urged to speed mergers that would consolidate industry; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's top economic advisers have presented him with proposals to rescue the American steel industry that would most heavily penalize China, Japan, Germany, Taiwan and South Korea, but exempt most poor nations -- and Mexico and Canada --...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and JOSEPH KAHN

docs.lead_paragraph: A dozen years ago, almost no one seemed less likely to become a crusader for human rights than John Kamm. He was the president of Hong Kong's American Chamber of Commerce and a regional vice president of Occidental Chemical Corporation, a multinational company that, in addition to paying Kamm very handsomely, provided him with a luxury apartment, a Mercedes and driver, two maids, a cost-of-living allowance, private-school tuition for his sons and paid home leave. He had few reasons to rock the boat. In May 1990, Kamm was preparing to go to Washington to testify before Congress that China's human rights record should not get in the way of granting the country Most Favored Nation trading status. This, of course, was the position of both the Chinese government and the Americans doing business in China, who desperately sought the lower tariffs that M.F.N. would provide. But since the Tiananmen Square massacre the previous year, the debate in the United States over China's trade status had grown acrimonious. The democracy protests in Tiananmen and the subsequent massacre -- hundreds killed, more than 10,000 detained or arrested in the immediate aftermath -- had turned human rights in China into a topic of discussion in living rooms across America. Many members of Congress were now groping for ways to force China to respect human rights, and M.F.N. was one of the few tools available.
docs.abstract: Tina Rosenberg article on John Kamm and his evolution from businessman into crusader for human rights in China; cites his role in gaining release of political prisoners; holds American executives' endorsement of China's leadership undercuts beneficial effects of engagement on human rights; Kamm says foreign businesses can speak out for human rights without putting their profits at risk; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A dozen years ago, almost no one seemed less likely to become a crusader for human rights than John Kamm. He was the president of Hong Kong's American Chamber of Commerce and a regional vice president of Occidental Chemical Corporation, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: JUDGING from its recent financial results, Eckerd, the big drugstore chain owned by J. C. Penney, is going strong. J. Wayne Harris, Eckerd's relatively new chief executive, was hired to turn it around, and he appears to have done the job. But from another vantage point, Eckerd has hit some nasty bumps. At least two states are investigating the chain for possible overbilling in its pharmacies, and it is the subject of a class-action suit contending that the company routinely charged customers for medications they did not receive. In Texas, an insurance company sued Eckerd last November, contending that it overbilled for medications in workers' compensation claims.

headline.main: A Rebound, Yes, but the Price May Be High

docs.abstract: Troubled past of J Wayne Harris, Eckerd drugstore chain's relatively new chief executive, discussed in light of questions being raised about chain's billing practices; J C Penney chief executive Allen Questrom, who hired Harris to head unit, defends him; Harris has transformed Eckerd, which generated operating profit of $208 million for year ended Jan 26, compared with year-earlier $76 million loss; table of alleged drug overcharges; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TO Koichiro Kitade, Japan is part paradise, part paradox. Mr. Kitade, director of the Citigroup Private Bank here, has the enviable task of finding clients who hold part of the country's vast $10.5 trillion in personal savings. There are plenty of wealthy people here, but battered by recession, deflation and a lack of choices, the Japanese are among the world's most tightfisted investors. More than half their money is stashed in savings accounts that earn almost no interest. By most reckoning, though, Mr. Kitade appears to have solved a riddle that has perplexed bankers here for years: how to persuade the Japanese to move even a fraction of their money into potentially more rewarding investments. Amid the rubble of Japan's financial system, sales at Citigroup's private banking services, which are open to investors with assets of at least 300 million yen ($2.3 million), have grown more than 25 percent a year for four years.

headline.main: Only Japan's Wealthy Welcome at This Bank

docs.abstract: Citigroup Private Bank has carved out niche in Japan's insular and sometimes hostile financial markets, with sales up over 25 percent a year for four years; serves investors with assets of at least 300 million yen ($2.3 million); director Koichiro Kitade comments, interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time, all you had to do was build a better mousetrap. Today, what supposedly counts is how well you market that mousetrap. Marketing gurus abound. When I typed in ''marketing'' at Amazon.com, 13,880 or so book titles sprang up. But it's a safe bet that few, if any, urge businesses to scare their customers into buying their products. Yet fear-based marketing seems to be all around us.

headline.main: Buy! Buy! But the World Won't End if You Don't

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column deplores fear-based marketing, holding it has become mainstream to our collective detriment; cites sales of extended warranties to expand profits on low-margin goods; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The major economies of the world are at present like trains side by side at a station. One or the other may be moving forward a bit, but it's hard for passengers looking out the window to tell whether it's their train or the one on the next track that is actually moving. Things are that slow, and may remain so for a time. At least in America's case, any backward movement has ceased. The Commerce Department announced Thursday that in the last quarter of 2001, the nation's economic output rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent. That better-than-expected performance was driven by strong consumer spending and is a tribute to the resilience of the American economy in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. In all of last year, the economy grew by a meager tenth of 1 percent.
docs.abstract: Editorial on current slow economic growth notes there is some doubt whether US was ever really in recession; notes outlook is uncertain, with few analysts expecting typical recovery to follow most atypical slump; lauds Federal Reserve efforts to boost economy; sees resumption of business investment needed to drive recovery; urges House Republicans to stop linking needed extension of unemployment benefits to further reckless tax cuts

docs.lead_paragraph: Q I am a tenant shareholder in a co-op in Westchester County and I recently received a letter from the board increasing from $10 to $25 the late fee charged for maintenance payments received after the 10th of the month. The board is now also requiring every tenant shareholder to carry homeowners insurance coverage of at least $100,000. Does the board have the legal authority to enforce these new rules? . . . John E. Cannon, Bronxville, N.Y. A Kenneth R. Jacobs, a co-op lawyer who has offices in Manhattan and Yonkers, said that while most co-ops impose late charges on delinquent maintenance payments, the ability of the board to increase the late charges depends on the co-op's proprietary lease.

headline.main: A Co-op's Late Fees, and Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a girl in Queens in the 1970's Harriet P. Pearson, ''Star Trek'' fan and nature lover, thought she might become an environmentalist. Instead, she has wound up, at 38, as the chief privacy officer for I.B.M. As Ms. Pearson sees it, the way people use, manage and safeguard information is as essential in this century as environmental concerns were in the last. At I.B.M., her role is to oversee everything from the corporation's handling of employee data to devising systems to help protect privacy. In short, to be accountable at every level for the way I.B.M. manages its chief currency, information.
docs.abstract: Interview with Harriet P Pearson, chief privacy officer for IBM, who comments on importance of protecting employee and customer data and helping customers meet their own privacy needs; photo (M)
